Pre-Game Insights: Rain threatens high stakes India-Australia clash at T20 World Cup
Finch: Head vs Bumrah will be a great battle
This episode of Australia-India was always going to be spicy
Group 1 of the Super Eight in T20 World Cup 2024 is now thrillingly open
Australia will be on wafer-thin ice if they lose
India's net run rate gives them a decent safety net
The weather forecast in St Lucia isn't hugely encouraging
A washout would suit India just fine, sealing their semi-finals spot
Mitchell Marsh has scored 88 runs in six innings at an average of 17.60 and a strike rate of 111.39
Arshdeep Singh is India's highest wicket-taker in this World Cup with 12 strikes at the rate of one every 10 balls
Australia played the extra spinner against Afghanistan, bringing in Ashton Agar and leaving out Mitchell Starc

Australia (probable): 1 Travis Head, 2 David Warner, 3 Mitchell Marsh (capt), 4 Glenn Maxwell, 5 Marcus Stoinis, 6 Tim David, 7 Matthew Wade (wk), 8 Pat Cummins, 9 Mitchell Starc/Ashton Agar, 10 Adam Zampa, 11 Josh Hazlewood

India (probable): 1 Rohit Sharma (capt), 2 Virat Kohli, 3 Rishabh Pant (wk), 4 Suryakumar Yadav, 5 Shivam Dube, 6 Hardik Pandya, 7 Axar Patel, 8 Ravindra Jadeja, 9 Arshdeep Singh, 10 Kuldeep Yadav, 11 Jasprit Bumrah
St Lucia has been the most batting-friendly venue of this T20 World Cup in terms of both scoring rate (8.92) and average (28.76)
There is a good chance of rain in St Lucia, with forecasts predicting showers through Monday morning with the weather clearing up roughly between 10am and 4pm
Post-Match Reflections: Australia captain Mitchell Marsh: 'We have a lot of belief in our group. We are a very good cricket team. Yes, tonight we had an off night but I guess there's also a positive in the fact that in 36 hours we go again. It's a big game, it will be against India, obviously, and it's a must-win game. I think if you look back at the short history of this team, I know for a fact that it brings out the best in our guys, so the boys will certainly be up and about for it.'

India captain Rohit Sharma: 'In T20s, I don't believe you need to get fifties and hundreds. How you can put pressure on the opposition is what matters. All the batters were trying to do that from the word go. That's how we want to play and encourage ourselves to go forward. Yes, you need to understand the conditions as well, but we have a lot of experience in the squad, and we back them to use that experience on the field.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: India have a 3-2 edge over Australia in their T20 World Cup meetings so far
Virat Kohli (4103) and Rohit Sharma (4073) are separated by just 30 runs on top of India's run-scoring leaderboard in T20Is
If they both feature, Agar and Arshdeep will play their 50th T20Is
Australia could find a way to bowl spin to Kohli and Rohit in the powerplay even if they leave Agar out
Glenn Maxwell could be a useful option
